titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to Special Collections in the Music Division of the Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2010

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Billy Byers was a composer, arranger, orchestrator, and musician (trombonist). The collection primarily contains full scores in Byers' hand. It represents a sampling of Byers' work as a composer, arranger, and orchestrator. The material shows the diverse styles, musical forces, and variety of performing venues in which he worked. The scores include works for recordings, live performances, television, and film; for small combos, big bands, and orchestras; and for singers of various styles, including pop, jazz, rock, rhythm and blues, and disco.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: In 1997, the Library of Congress was contacted by Edward Joffe, a musician and teacher at the New Jersey City University. Joffe had played in the orchestra for the last show that Billy Byers had orchestrated, Victor/Victoria, and the two had become friends in the last two years of Byers’ life. Joffe acquired several of Byers’ arrangements for Count Basie and Frank Sinatra when Byers had visited him, along with their mutual friend Bill Caiza. Caiza mentioned that he had acquired these scores when working for Byers’ primary copyist, Emile Charlap, and offered them back to Byers; instead, Byers suggested that he give them to Joffe. Eventually, Joffe felt that the scores should have a more permanent home where they would be available to generations of musicians and scholars; an inquiry at the Rodgers & Hammerstein Organization led to the suggestion that the Music Division of the Library of Congress would be an ideal place to house the collection. Joffe gave the scores to the Library, and assisted the Library in contacting Byers’ widow, Yuriko Byers, in the hopes that she would have additional scores that she might be willing to give to the Library as well.
Ms. Byers had several cartons of additional scores by her husband and was delighted to give them to the Library, also in 1997, to form the largest component of the Billy Byers Collection.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Mark Horowitz processed the Billy Byers Collection in 2003 and wrote the finding aid using WordPerfect, version 12. Nancy Seeger coded the finding aid for EAD in 2010.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Materials from the Billy Byers Collection are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Billy Byers Collection is open to research.
Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.

Researchers may make single copies of items in the collection, but should be warned that various permissions are likely to be required in order to perform or record these arrangements and orchestrations.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Billy Byers Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The following chronology is not complete, but rather represents highlights from Byers’ career–particularly items where agreement on dates and titles came from multiple sources. Most of Byers’ work as a musician is not included here, most notably the dozens of recordings on which he played the trombone. Distinctions between the term arranger and orchestrator are not always used consistently in various sources, so those differing designations here should not be taken as definitive.

chronitem.event: Born William Mitchell Byers III in Los Angeles, Calif.
Began piano lessons
Began trombone lessons
Onset of arthritis forced him to give up keyboard performance; began scoring films
Played with the Karl Kiffe’s Hollywood Canteen Kids Band
Graduated from Van Nuys High School; attended Harvard where he studied law for one year
Joined the Army Air Force
Trombonist and arranger for Georgie Auld, Buddy Rich and Benny Goodman
Trombonist and arranger for Charlie Ventura and Teddy Powell; joined the staff of WMGM in New York; at 23 became arranger for Your Show of Shows television program
Moved to Paris; musical director for American films made in France by United International Pictures; worked with Charles Aznavour
Arranged Milt Hinton’s recording Basses Loaded
Recorded Jazz on the Left Bank; arranged Coleman Hawkins’ recording The Hawk in Hi Fi ; arranged Gene Krupa’s recording Drummer Man
Performed with Ray Ventura in France
Composed film score for Le Grand bluff; returned to New York and joined a small radio band; active in the RCA Jazz Workshop
Performed with Johnny Richards orchestra; arranged recording Eydie Gorme on Stage
Returned to Paris; composed film scores
Toured Europe in Quincy Jones’ orchestra for Harold Arlen’s blues opera Free and Easy
Arranged Quincy Jones’ recording Swiss Radio Days Jazz Series, vol. 1
Quincy Jones’ assistant at Mercury Records; arranged music for a series of albums by Count Basie
Taught Paul Newman to play trombone for film Paris Blues
Arranged music for recordings Impressions of Duke Ellington and Peggy Lee’s Sugar ‘n Spice
Marries Yuriko Saito
Daughter Kimiko Byers was born
Arranger/orchestrator for Count Basie’s recording More Hits of the 50's and 60's and for Frankly Basie: Count Basie Plays the Hits of Frank Sinatra ; orchestrated recording The Beast in Me
Orchestrated film The Pawnbroker
Son Bryant Byers was born
Arranged recordings Basie Picks the Winners and Chris Connor Sings Gentle Bossa Nova; arranger/conductor/orchestrator on Sarah Vaughan Sings the Mancini Songbook
Moved to Malibu
Composed film score for Young American
Composed film score for Hawks and Doves
Composed scores for the films Go for Croak, A Pair of Greenbacks and The Tijuana Toads; orchestrated film Music Box
Composed film scores for Dopey Hacienda, Hop and Chop, and The Froggy, Froggy Duo; and television score for Hauser’s Memory
Daughter Michiko Byers was born
Composed for television show Streets of San Francisco and film Flight to the Finish
Musical director/conductor for Rod McKuen’s television show The Borrowers; composed for Barnaby Jones television program; orchestrator on film scores for The Sting and The Way We Were
Toured Europe and Japan as trombonist with Frank Sinatra; musical director for the film Mame; composed film score for Moonchild
Orchestrator for A Chorus Line ; musical director for the film White Line Fever
Orchestrated film score for Silent Movie; arranger/orchestrator on film score for Richard Rodgers–The Sound of His Music
Musical director for television show Happy Birthday, Las Vegas
Orchestrator/arranger for film Same Time Next Year and for television shows Ben Vereen and His Roots and Steve and Eydie Celebrate Irving Berlin
Orchestrated stage show A New York Summer; composed score for television program Hanging In; arranger/conductor on Sarah Vaughan’s recording The Duke Ellington Songbook, vol. 1
Orchestrated stage show Perfectly Frank; won Emmy Award for arranging television show Linda in Wonderland; won Emmy Award as principal arranger for television show Baryshnikov on Broadway
Orchestrated stage shows Broadway Follies and Hello to Harvey; wins Emmy nomination as principal arranger for Walt Disney: One Man’s Dream
Orchestrated A Doll’s Life for the stage; arranger/orchestrator for film Sophie’s Choice and television program Shirley MacLaine–Illusions “On the Outside Looking In”
Orchestrated stage shows Chaplin and 5,6,7,8...Dance!; won Emmy nomination as principal arranger for television show Epcot Center: The Opening Celebration

Conducted film score for Joyeuses Pâques a.k.a. Happy Easter; orchestrated opening ceremonies for the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles; won Emmy Award as principal arranger for The Screen Actor’s Guild 50th Anniversary Celebration

Orchestrated Grind for the stage; moved to Paris; conducted film score for Hors-la-loi a.k.a. Outlaws; created arrangements for the Lido de Paris!; Emmy Award as principal arranger for Christmas in Washington
Conducted film scores for Every Time We Say Goodbye and Pirates; orchestrated the film Le Lieu du Crime
Orchestrated Smile for the stage; orchestrated the film Les Innocents
Orchestrated the film L’Ours a.k.a. The Bear
Won Emmy Award as arranger for Julie Andrews in Concert on Great Performances; Emmy nomination as arranger for The 62nd Annual Academy Awards; arranged Mandy Patinkin’s recording Dress Casual

Orchestrated The Will Rogers Follies for the stage; Emmy Award as principal arranger for The Walt Disney Company Presents “The American Teacher Awards; Emmy nomination as arranger for Christmas in Washington; arranger/conductor on Barry Manilow’s recording Showstoppers
Arranged on the Boston Pops recording Unforgettable; orchestrator on Liza Minnelli’s recording Live from Radio City

Arranger/conductor on Barbra Streisand’s recording Back to Broadway; arranger on the Boston Pops’ recording Night and Day; arranger on Frank Sinatra’s recording Duets; arranger on Michael Feinstein’s recording Forever; orchestrated The Goodbye Girl for the stage
Arranger on Barbara Cook’s recording Live from London and Frank Sinatra’s recording Duets II
Orchestrated Victor/Victoria for the stage; orchestrated Mandy Patinkin’s recording Oscar and Steve as well as Oh Brother for both stage and recording
Orchestrated Julie Andrews’ recording Here I’ll Stay: The Words of Alan Jay Lerner and Leonard Bernstein’s New York; orchestrated portions of the recording The Life
Died of cancer
Posthumously given the American Society of Music Arrangers and Composers Irwin Kostal Award

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection represents neither all nor most of Byers’ work as a composer, arranger and orchestrator, but provides a sampling of the diverse styles, musical forces, variety of performers and situations that he worked for and with. The scores here range from works for recordings, live performances, television shows, and film scores; for groups that range from small combos to big bands to orchestras of symphonic proportions; and for an eclectic array of singers, from pop to jazz to rock to rhythm and blues to disco; and even dancers. Missing here are any of Byers’ arrangements and orchestrations for Broadway musicals. It is hoped that someday this gap, too, will be filled by other collections in the Library.
Unless otherwise noted, all items in the Billy Byers Collection are full scores in Byers’ hand, and most of these are in ink on transparencies.

The collection came to the Library with most of the scores in envelopes marked in alphabetical order, usually marked with the name of a performer, but occasionally marked with the name of a project or a song title. We have retained that organization as closely as possible. In some cases, this arrangement results in scores for the same project ending up in different places. For instance, there were several envelopes marked “Steve and Eydie” which contained, among other things, scores for the television special Steve and Eydie Celebrate Irving Berlin. There were also scores for the same show in envelopes for the performers Carol Burnett and Sammy Davis Jr. Rather than put these scores together, we have kept them in the original order, but have included cross-references to help researchers find related materials. There are a few scores that may well have been inadvertently placed in the wrong envelopes before coming to the Library; for example, “Intro to 3 girls revised” which was included with the Ann-Margret materials. Unless there was additional evidence which convinced us that this was a mistake (such as an entry for this item appearing in another designation in the notebook inventorying the collection), we left it where it was found, but added a cross-reference–in this case to Three Girls Three.

In addition to song/work titles, other relevant information that appears on title pages is included in our listing following the colon. This information is often a date, a show title, the name of a record label, or some other piece of information that might help the researcher better identify the piece. Several of the scores include the designation “vaudeville.” We inquired of several people who had worked with Byers about the use of this term. The best guess was provided by the conductor Ian Fraser, who thought it indicated that fees for the arrangement had been calculated according to the scale charged for a live performance (original use); if the arrangement subsequently was used on a recording or as part of a television performance, an additional fee might be charged.

Because most of the collection is organized by the name of a performer, we have added a song index at the back of the finding aid. This index also includes songs we were able to identify among the many medleys (we were not able to identify all of them). It does not include the individual cue titles found in the film scores; instead, the major work titles for those films are indexed by “Miscellaneous cues.”
